messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, I remember that tsuba from before, having a discussion about it. Is it not sails of a ship appearing behind the islets on the horizon. With artistic
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich, I remember that tsuba from before, having a discussion about
it. Is it not sails of a ship appearing behind the islets on the
horizon. With artistic license of course. John

messages.messageBody:
Steve, Barry, & Milt,

Thanks. I believe that is exactly it.
Now the follow up question.-
Is this Akasaka tsuba a theme reference to Matsushima,
reference to something else, or just an Autumn theme?

http://tinyurl.com/32vfje

Best,

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Question on Tsuba Theme
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, Could your location be Matsushima??? http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5100.html I had the place in my mind but couldn t for the life of me remember its
messages.messageBody:
Curran,

Could your location be Matsushima???

http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5100.html

I had the place in my mind but couldn't for the life of me remember its name. I found it here, which site may also be of interest to others:

http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e623a.html

As to the poetry connection, try this (google keywords [ matsushima poem ] no quotes):

http://www.cs.rice.edu/~ssiyer/minstrels/poems/1021.html

and this

http://www.jref.com/practical/matsushima.shtml
which has the comment: "The great poet Bashou Matsuo (1644-1694) came here and exclaimed in one of his most famous Haiku poem : "Matsushima, Ah! Matsushima! Matsushima!"."

Regards,

Barry Thomas.


----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihonto@yahoogroups.com ; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, April 13, 2007 6:08 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Question on Tsuba Theme


List,

A while back the theme of:

"Small pine trees on small rock islands,
surrounded by wind and waves"

was discussed on one of the lists as a reference to a
particular place, and I believe to a poem. Can anyone
refresh my memory as to the location and relevance of
this place (& theme)?

Curran
.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
